RESIDENT INCOME TAX
(Collection)


    3. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Financial Secretary whether he will take measures analogous to those prevailing in almost all other territories to prevent the departure of residents until their Income Tax has been paid or a sufficient guarantee obtained for payment thereof.

    Mr T. M. Hart: It is not clear, Sir, what measures the hon. Member has in mind. In Australia and New Zealand, where geographical position confers a distinct advantage, there is a system of tax clearances whereby shipping and aircraft operators are prohibited from issuing passenger tickets without the production of a certificate that outstanding income tax has been paid. Limited forms of this system exist in India, Pakistan and the United States, but Ceylon relies on the same powers as exist in the Malayan Income Tax Ordinance. The possibility of introducing a system similar to that existing in Australia and New Zealand has been considered on a number of occasions. On each occasion, however, it has been decided not to proceed with the proposal for the following reasons:

    (a) the ease with which a really determined tax evader can leave the territory without purchasing a passenger ticket;

Column: 747



    (b) the large number of transit passengers visiting Singapore for varying periods and the very large number of residents who leave Singapore for varying periods;

    (c) the difficulty of providing the comparatively large staff which would be required to enforce such a system at a time when the Department is still having the greatest difficulty in obtaining staff for the assessment and collection of tax from resident individuals and companies;

    (d) the cost of enforcing the system in terms of cash and diverted effort which would be disproportionate to the amount of tax recovered;

    (e) the great inconvenience which would be caused to a great number of law-abiding citizens of Singapore who have to leave the territory on business from time to time.

    Mr Marshall: If it please you, Sir, I would ask whether the Financial Secretary would consider, in view of the grave position disclosed by the figures, the immediate introduction of provisions which prevent a person, who has been in Singapore for more than three months, leaving Malaya - this must be a pan-Malayan measure - without a clearance from the Malayan income tax authorities.

    Mr Hart: First of all, Sir, the position is not grave. The figures which I quoted in answer to the first question indicate quite clearly that the Income Tax Department is very rapidly getting on top of this particular problem. We are at the present moment considering amending the Income Tax Ordinance to give power to the Comptroller to call upon employers to make returns of employees joining their organisations and employees leaving their organisations and to give warning of the impending departure of employees. Any system whereby shipping and aircraft operators who are required to have income tax clearance certificates before they issue passenger tickets would require joint

LUXURY TAX BILL


    Order for second reading read.

10.13 a.m.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): Sir, I have His Excellency the Governor's authority to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This, Sir, is a complicated Bill. As hon. Members will see from the Comparative Table which appears on page 25, the Law Officers, in drafting, have referred extensively to United Kingdom Finance Acts, thus taking advantage of the long experience of the United Kingdom in the matter of luxury and purchase taxes. The explanatory note at page 23 of the Bill serves as a useful guide to these provisions. Perhaps I may be allowed to outline some of them, Sir.

    Part I contains definitions which require careful study.

    Part II calls for no comment.

    Part III is most important. It deals with the nature and scope and method of imposition of a luxury tax. Clause 8 (1) prescribes that the tax should be charged on the wholesale value of all chargeable goods bought under chargeable purchases. The Governor in Council is vested with the power of deciding what goods shall be subject to tax and at what rates. Any order in this connection, however, must be ratified by the Assembly within seven days. Clause 8 (4) defines a chargeable purchase as "any purchase made from a wholesale merchant or manufacturer selling by wholesale". Purchases made by a registered wholesale merchant or a registered manufacturer of goods as stock for business or as materials are exempt from tax. Clause 8 (5) specifies

Column: 750

that the tax will become due on delivery of the goods under the purchase and the seller shall be accountable for tax. Clause 8 (6) states that tax will be charged on the wholesale value of all chargeable goods imported into the colony except goods imported by registered wholesale merchants or manufacturers. Clause 8 (7) states the circumstances and conditions under which goods may be imported tax free by registered wholesale merchants and manufacturers. Clause 8 (9) exempts from tax goods imported for re-export or transhipment under certain conditions.

    Clause 9 defines "wholesale value" as the price which, in the opinion of the Comptroller, the goods would fetch on a sale by wholesale in the open market in the Colony to a retail trader carrying on business in the Colony and if it were made in the circumstances specified in the First Schedule to the Bill.

    Clause 10 deals with the registration of wholesale merchants and manufacturers whose business includes the selling of any chargeable goods. Clause 10 (2) provides that a manufacturer who is not required to be registered under the Ordinance shall be so registered if he satisfies the Comptroller that he uses chargeable goods in substantial quantities as materials. Clause 10 (3) provides that persons who should be registered must make application to the Comptroller. Clause 10 (4) provides that any wholesale merchant or manufacturer who finds that the proviso to clause 10 (1) no longer applies to him, shall immediately apply for registration. Clause 10 (6) provides for the issue of a certificate of registration, and the Comptroller may in certain circumstances call for security for the payment of tax.

    Clause 11 contains provisions whereby the Comptroller shall exempt a person from registration when the tax on his purchases shall be not less than the tax on his sales; in other words, where the tax payable on his purchases and importations in respect of stock or materials would be more than the tax he would be accountable for on his sales.

Column: 751



    Clause 12 prescribes when a purchase shall be deemed a purchase by a registered wholesale merchant as stock or by a registered manufacturer as materials, and therefore exempt from tax.

    Clause 13 provides for relief against a double charge of tax.

    Clause 14 states that, where a registered wholesale merchant or manufacturer appropriates or applies any chargeable goods in his ownership to the purposes of any business carried on by him of selling chargeable goods by retail or of letting out chargeable goods on hire or to any other purpose not being a sale of the goods, the appropriation or application shall be treated as if it were a chargeable purchase.

    Clause 15 (1) prescribes that, when any person required to be registered applies a chargeable process, tax shall be chargeable on the wholesale value of the resulting goods and shall become due on the completion of the process. The person who applies the process shall be accountable for the tax. Clause 15 (2) exempts persons who apply a chargeable process from accountability for tax when the goods are his property at the time of the completion of the process, subject, of course, to the provisions of clause 14.

    Clause 16 provides that any person who carries out a chargeable process shall be treated as a manufacturer whose business includes the selling of chargeable goods.

    Clause 17 states that any retail trader purchasing on a wholesale scale shall be treated as a wholesale merchant.

    Clause 18 states that the seller of chargeable goods under a chargeable purchase shall add the amount due in tax to any invoice issued by him.

    Clause 19 provides relief for exported goods. Under subclause (1) the Comptroller may exempt from tax goods which would otherwise be chargeable if they were exported from the colony. Under subclause (2) the Financial Secretary may give directions for the payment of an allowance for tax paid or payable in respect of goods exported when the Comptroller is satisfied that the conditions specified in the subclause exist.

Column: 752



    It will be seen, Sir, that the Bill gives wide powers to the administration. Any goods can be deemed luxury goods and any rate of tax imposed on them by the Governor in Council, subject, of course, to the approval of the Assembly.

    Again the Comptroller of Customs, who is responsible for the care and management of the tax, is given wide powers under a number of clauses. The wide discretion given to the Comptroller has apparently been a cause of anxiety to the Bar Council which has addressed the Attorney-General and other Members of the Assembly on the subject. In particular, the Bar Council takes objection to the Comptroller's powers under clauses 9, 17 and 26. Note has been taken of these objections and they will be given careful consideration in due course, and doubtless when this Bill is sent to Select Committee, the Members of the Committee will consider their objections too.

    Government has also given consideration to the question of local industries and has decided, as a measure of encouragement, to exempt from tax all goods entirely manufactured locally and also goods in respect of which a certain percentage of their wholesale value has been expended locally. The necessary amendments to the text of the Bill will be moved in Committee in due course.

    Justification for this Bill is that Government will have to tap all sources of revenue in the future, and luxury goods appear to be a justifiable source of revenue. As I said earlier, very considerable sums of money are spent each year on goods which cannot, by any stretch of the imagination, be deemed essential or even desirable. If confirmation of this statement is required, one has only to look about one, in the shop windows, in the homes of people in Singapore and at people proceeding about their lawful occasions. That being so, it is only proper that Government should have some small share of the sums spent on luxury goods. A great majority of countries in the world today impose taxes on goods which are outside the "essential" category. In the great majority of cases, the tax is imposed on the wholesale price.

Column: 753



    It would not be possible to give any estimate of the possible yield from this tax until it is decided what commodities should be taxed. In selecting goods to be taxed, careful consideration will be given to the nature and needs of the entrepot trade. In so far as it is possible, having regard to the needs of the revenue, goods which enter largely into trade with neighbouring countries will be avoided. Where entrepot trade goods have to be included, efforts will be made to reduce inconvenience to traders to a minimum.

    It was to be expected that this Bill would be a controversial measure. It is novel and involves a radical departure from previous taxation principles in Singapore. For these reasons, it was decided to allow a period of time to elapse between the First and Second Readings and subsequently to send the Bill to Select Committee. This will allow full ventilation of views and discussion as to the merits and principles underlying the Bill, both in and out of the Assembly.

    In connection with discussion outside the Assembly, it has been suggested that the Bill means the death of free trade in Singapore, and, that being so, that it would be simpler and more straightforward to impose import duties right away. It certainly would be simpler, but it would be contrary to the intentions of Government. Singapore's prosperity has been built on trade and, no matter what industrial expansion takes place in the future, will continue to depend on trade, on free trade and on freedom to trade. Government is fully aware of the need not only to maintain but also to increase trade. As I have said earlier, all Government's development planning starts from the premise that Singapore must be maintained as a centre of world trade. In the circumstances, it is extremely unlikely that this Government, or indeed any government except one bent on the destruction of Singapore, would introduce any law or make regulations under such a law which would undermine the prosperity of the port.

    I hope that hon. Members will speak frankly on this measure so that their views can be considered by the Select Committee and by Government in due course. Sir, I beg to move.

Column: 754



    Question proposed.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, we have before us a Bill to tax luxury goods. Whatever its name, it is a fundamental departure from the free trade policy of Singapore which has continued for over a century. Sir, I hope the Government Members will forgive me if I am harsh with them. They have just come into power and that power of minority has been exercised with three ex-officio Members and four nominated Members.

    The Government has already said that there will be new elections in August. If that is so, is it wise on their part to push through such a Bill which is just like committing a crime on Singapore? It is a departure from principles and that is why I say it is a crime.

    Sir, I might also say that the present Coalition Government cannot claim that they represent the trading interests.

    Mr Marshall: We do not.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: They will say, "Why? We do not care." But I will say this: as Singapore exists on entrepot trade, it is trade that brings in the money, and the workers, the wage-earners and the farmers can only flourish by working together hand in hand. We have no natural resources, none whatsoever. How far and to what extent is the Government going to tax? There is a limit and we have reached this limit - that the Government is forced, by their extravagance, to kill the free trade policy of this country.

    Sir, what is luxury? The term "luxury goods" has not been defined. If the Government wants to bring in a few items under this category, as it has already done with motor-cars, by all means describe what are luxury goods and place an imposition on them. But to pass this Bill and give such powers to the Government or any future government, there is a danger that it might mishandle the powers and everything might be included under the category of luxury goods, because money is necessary to run the government. It is said that safeguards will be provided

Column: 755

which will ensure that the Government will not do this or that in order to preserve our entrepot trade. What is the guarantee that another government will not do this or that since the Ordinance is in force? We on the Opposition Benches are not willing to give such powers to the Government.

    Sir, to produce money you have to spend first on starting a department. You have to have a vast establishment. You have to have bonded warehouses ultimately if not immediately. This is necessary if money is to come in. We must have inspectors and clerks, etc. for these warehouses. Then, Sir, we have to guard against corruption.

    Sir, I have been in business here since 1916. I have been President of the Indian Chamber of Commerce for several years. I have been to E.C.A.F.E. conferences and I have heard about the trading conditions of other countries and I have compared ours with theirs. With what little experience that I have, I would urge the Government not to proceed with this Bill. I am glad that the Financial Secretary has said that some time will elapse before this measure will be brought before the Assembly and that a Select Committee will be appointed to consider it. All this is good, but I would ask, "Why is all this necessary?" How much more money is wanted during the next 8 months while this Government remains in power? It can raise the money by income tax or any other tax but not by this Luxury Tax Bill.

    Sir, who will suffer as a result of the imposition of this luxury tax on goods? The majority of the population on this small island are the workers and wage-earners. Sir, I have never been personal in my remarks, but I would like to quote the remarks of the Minister for Communications and Works which I read yesterday in the Press. I was not present when he was speaking. Sir, I have great respect for the school-master's knowledge in theory -

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Whose side?

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: The Government side. It was very interesting to hear

Column: 756

his arguments on socialism and so on, but let me remind him. He said yesterday, subject to correction, that there was no need for gold ornaments or something like that which I read in the Press.

    The Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Thomas) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Is the hon. Member giving way?

    Mr R. Jumabhoy resumed his seat.

    Mr Francis Thomas: What I said yesterday was that it was desirable to mobilise all hoardings of unfruitful capital used up in gold ornaments or in dollar notes tucked away in cupboards and not put to productive use.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Thank you; I would say that the Europeans can never understand the Asian way of life.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Exactly!

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: It is a necessity for a poor man to save some money and because he has insufficient money to open a bank account, he invests his savings in gold ornaments. The Minister also spoke about remittances to India and China, but he forgot to say that billions of dollars have been drained away to the United Kingdom for 135 years.

    Sir, as I have asked, "What are luxury goods?"

    Mr Braga: Ask yourself!

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Everyone in Singapore uses scent, soaps, cosmetics, radios and refrigerators. They are necessities to the wage-earner, the clerk, the merchant or the rich man. By introducing this Bill, the Labour Front Coalition Government, which claims to be representative of the workers, will be imposing hardship on them. It would be a fine idea if the Government, after bringing in this Bill before the Assembly, were not to proceed with it. Orders must have been placed or goods have been hoarded by profiteers, and if the Bill is not proceeded with, the benefit will go to the public because these profiteers will have to sell their goods at

Column: 757

a cheaper price. In any case, during the next eight months while the Government remains in power, it will not do any good and it is not necessary for it to introduce this Bill. But if the necessity arises, then let a fully elected government by the people and for the people take the necessary measures to introduce a similar kind of Bill if it finds it necessary. Sir, in conclusion, I would request the Government not to proceed with this Bill which is not in the interests of the colony or the masses or anyone else.

10.36 a.m.

    Mr Marshall: If it please you, Sir, I support this measure unreservedly. The Member for Telok Ayer says - and he speaks rightly - that there is no person on this side of the House who represents trade. That is true, Sir, but I would also add that though we do not represent trade, we are and have always shown ourselves to be very conscious of the fact that Singapore survives by virtue of the activity of capital through trade and commerce in this territory and that our record does indicate that we have been conscious of this, and we are anxious that no harm shall be done to this aspect of our economic life.

    I believe, Sir, that the Member for Telok Ayer's fears are grounded on the fact that Government has not shown its hand as to what it believes or it considers to be luxuries; but I would draw his attention to this, Sir: this Bill is in the nature of the overall law which will control the tax on luxuries, but in fact the luxuries will be defined when the tax is applied; and seven days after it is applied, this House will have to confirm the decision. That is necessary, Sir, so that this step should, first of all, be progressive, and, secondly, we cannot now disclose what is in mind before the Bill is passed and thereby gives the importer an opportunity to pile up goods which may or may not be taxed afterwards.

    I would remind the House that the question of taxation on individual objects, subject to this tax proposed by Government, is still in the hands of the House; and supposing we bring in a tax on radios in two or three months' time,

Column: 758

then within seven days this House will have to decide whether or not radios are a luxury, and if they are, whether they are appropriate objects in the existing circumstances for the application of this tax. The House, in giving these overall powers, is in fact not giving power for application of this tax to individual articles. It is retaining that power and can exercise it when the Government comes before the House seeking confirmation of its desire to tax any particular type of object.

    Sir, I am happy to learn that this Bill will go before a Select Committee. It is a good measure and it should, as soon as possible, be on our statute book. But it is a difficult measure, a measure full of acute technical subtleties, and representations - some of which seem very valid - have been made by the Bar Committee with reference to various aspects. I think that a Select Committee is certainly appropriate to consider each and every individual phrase in the Bill, and I welcome the suggestion made by the Financial Secretary that this Bill will, in fact, if it passes its Second Reading, be submitted to a Select Committee.

    I have only one other remark to make on this measure, Sir. I welcome the statement of the Financial Secretary that local industry will receive direct encouragement by the exemption, in part, of those taxable luxury goods which are produced locally. I would like to go further. Our industrial-set up is in an extremely poor condition and I would like a large measure of assistance where possible to be given to it, and in this instance it is possible. I would like to see all luxury products, which are subject to this tax, exempted from taxation if produced locally. I also welcome the indication given by the Financial Secretary that products which are even partially produced in this colony, that is, in respect of which part of the cost is incurred in this colony, will be considered for partial exemption.

    Sir, this is a good measure, a necessary measure, a well-thought out measure, and I say with respect to the Member for Telok Ayer that I really do not see how it can affect our entrepot trade. The basis of our entrepot trade is the

produce from the East and the essentials from the West in which we deal. Luxury goods as such form but a very small proportion of our trade and we have been promised special arrangements for the entrepot trade in these luxury goods so that it would not in any way be impeded.

10.42 a.m.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, my objections to this Bill are three-fold. Firstly, any tax measure which endangers the free port status and the entrepot trade of Singapore is a bad measure and I am not convinced by the assurances of the hon. Gentlemen opposite that this will not have this effect. Secondly, the tax on certain luxuries, while intending to tax the rich, may, by a chain reaction, result in raising the cost of living for the poor man as well. Thirdly, such a tax reduces the buying and selling of goods and the contraction in trade in an island which lives or dies by trade can be suicidal.

    I notice that of all the definitions or interpretations which are made under clause 3 of this Bill, there is no definition of the most important term of all, the term "luxury". This makes us extremely suspicious of Government's intentions. Only yesterday I pointed out that small cars in certain circumstances are necessities. As the pressure of population increases, people have to live further from their offices and from schools while the public transport system lags inevitably further and further behind this development. Therefore it is essential that the Financial Secretary should give us a list of the articles which he has in mind to tax and a list beyond which he will in no circumstances go. Who knows otherwise whether textiles and clothing will not be counted as luxuries in time to come? In his speech on the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill the Financial Secretary stated as follows:

    "Even if the imposition of luxury taxes were to limit consumption of luxury goods, I should be perfectly happy since it would mean that the population saved more and had more to invest in the Government loans...".

This is a dangerously over-simplified argument and I am inclined to think

Column: 760

that the savings would go, according to taste, into company shares, gold and jewellery or into lottery tickets. It is as dangerous as the other argument that if you tax luxuries, you are necessarily only taxing the rich, an error into which the Minister for Commerce and Industry fell yesterday. Very often you will find that from such taxation it is the poor man who in the end is to suffer. Let me give an example. The Financial Secretary has given, as I have said, no indication what the Government regards as luxuries, but a little intelligent guessing suggests that refrigerators and air-conditioning sets might be on a short list of possibilities. Now, raising the price on these articles will restrict sales and, as a result of this, the consumption of electricity will drop; and it will drop during the 20 hours outside the peak period from 6 to 10 p.m., or, precisely, during those 20 hours when it is essential to sell as much electricity as possible. Let it not be forgotten that it is the purchasers of refrigerators and air-conditioning sets who spend more on electricity, and are therefore helping to keep down the price per unit of consumption. To make a complete generalisation - abolish all luxury electrical appliances and the price the poor man pays for his electric light will go up. Encourage the sale of these appliances by enabling more people to buy them and to use electricity, and it will be possible to lower the unit rate for lighting and lower the cost of living for the working man. May I quote a sentence from the 1955 Report of the Electricity Department of the City Council:
